    <td colspan=2 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>&nbsp; </td>
<td width=13 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr>
<td width=406 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;margin-left:17.3pt;text-indent:-8.65pt;'><font size=2>Accrued foreign exchange rate gain</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p ><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td colspan=2 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:right;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=2>(2,712</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p ><font size=2>)</font></p> </td>
<td colspan=2 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:right;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=2>&#151;</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p ><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr>
<td width=406 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td colspan=2 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <hr noshade width="100%" color="black" size=1> </td>
<td width=13 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td colspan=2 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <hr noshade width="100%" color="black" size=1> </td>
<td width=13 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr>
<td width=406 valign=bottom style='background:#EAF9E8; padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;margin-left:25.9pt;text-indent:-8.65pt;'><font size=2>Total gross deferred tax liabilities</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=bottom style='background:#EAF9E8;padding: 0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p ><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td colspan=2 valign=bottom style='background:#EAF9E8; padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:right;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=2>(6,758</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=bottom style='background:#EAF9E8;padding: 0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p ><font size=2>)</font></p> </td>
<td colspan=2 valign=bottom style='background:#EAF9E8; padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:right;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=2>&#151;</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=bottom style='background:#EAF9E8;padding: 0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p ><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr>
<td width=406 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td colspan=2 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <hr noshade width="100%" color="black" size=1> </td>
<td width=13 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td colspan=2 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <hr noshade width="100%" color="black" size=1> </td>
<td width=13 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr>
<td width=406 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;margin-left:17.3pt;text-indent:-8.65pt;'><font size=2>Net deferred tax assets</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p ><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td width=8 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:right;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=2>$</font></p> </td>
<td width=44 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:right;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=2>5,767</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p ><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td width=8 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:right;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td width=44 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:right;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=2>&#151;</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p ><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr>
<td width=406 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td width=13 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <hr noshade width="100%" color="black" size=3> </td>
<td valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <hr noshade width="100%" color="black" size=3> </td>
<td width=13 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <hr noshade width="100%" color="black" size=3> </td>
<td valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <hr noshade width="100%" color="black" size=3> </td>
<td width=13 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td> </tr> </table>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, management considers whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized. The ultimate realization of deferred tax </font></p>
<br><p style='margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center'><font size=2>F-15</font></p><br><HR noshade align=center width="100%" size=2>
<p style="page-break-before: always" align="center"><font size=2>HUNGARIAN TELEPHONE
  AND CABLE CORP. AND SUBSIDIARY</font><br>
  <font size="2">Notes to </font><font size=2>Consolidated Financial Statements
  </font><br>
  <font size=2> December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000</font><PAGE>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income during the periods in which those temporary differences and loss carryforwards are deductible. Determining the level of future taxable profits is inherently subjective and, to the extent that the Company&#146;s actual results differ from the forecasts, the asset may not be recovered. Based on the level of historical taxable income and projections of future taxable income over the periods in which the deferred tax assets are deductible, management believes it is more likely than not that the Company will realize the benefits of those deferred tax assets, net of the valuation allowance. The amount of the deferred tax asset considered realizable, however, could be reduced if estimates of future taxable income during the future periods are reduced. Management considers projected future taxable income and tax planning in making these assessments.
During 2002 and 2001, the valuation allowance decreased by $10,937,000 and $2,250,000, respectively.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(8)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><u><font size=2>Commitments and Contingencies</font></u></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(a)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Concession Agreements</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company has concession agreements with the Information and Communication Ministry, as successor to the Prime Minister&#146;s Office and the Ministry of Transportation, Telecommunications and Water Management (in all cases, &#147;the Ministry&#148;), to own and operate local public telephone networks in five regions of Hungary. Each of the concession agreements is for a term of 25 years, ending in 2019, and provided for an eight-year exclusivity period up to November 2002. Currently, the Company, is in the process of negotiating with the Ministry on the mutual termination or amendment of the concession agreements, as these are not compatible with the liberalised telecommunications market following the introduction of Act XL of 2001 on Communications (the &#147;Communications Act&#148;) on December 23, 2001.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(b)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Annual Concession Fees </font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company&#146;s concession agreements provide for the payment by the Company of annual concession fees of between 0.1% and 2.3% of net telephone service revenues depending on the concession area. The Company accrued the annual concession fee amounts for 2001 of HUF 157 million (approximately $0.7 million at December 31, 2002 exchange rates), but as of December 31, 2002 has not paid this amount. It has neither accrued for nor paid the annual concession fees for 2002, which would total approximately HUF 142 million (approximately $0.6 million at December 31, 2002 exchange rates). The Communications Act has replaced the concession system with a notification system under which new operators may offer telecommunications services in competition with the Company in the Company&#146;s operating areas merely upon notification to the Communications Authority and the payment of a nominal fee of HUF 10,000
(approximately $40 at December 31, 2002 exchange rates). A new operator would require a license if it intended to use radio frequencies, to build its own network or to allocate a number range to subscribers, but the granting of such licenses is by-and-large an administrative matter. The Company paid one-time concession fees to the Hungarian state when the concessions were originally granted and it was expected that if, after the expiry of the eight-year exclusivity periods, the state were to grant new operators rights to compete against the Company in its operating areas, such rights would have been granted following a tender, with the new operators having to pay a more than nominal fee for the rights in the same manner that the Company originally paid for its concessions. </font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The concession agreements contain an equal treatment clause that explicitly states that the Minister should not treat the concession company in an unequal or prejudicial manner compared to other telecommunications companies. The Company believes that the move from the concession system to the notification system, a system in which there are effectively no barriers to entry, breached its legitimate expectation that the Company would continue to benefit from the one-off concession fees it paid even after the end of its exclusivity periods because any competitor would also have to make a real investment in the form of the tender fee or similar in order to compete. </font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>Pending the outcome of the current negotiations on the mutual termination or amendment of the concession agreements, the Company has thus far withheld the payment of the concession fees for 2001.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>For 2002, the Company believes that it is not required to pay concession fees at all. In addition to the local loop unbundling obligations, the Communications Act imposed universal service obligations on </font></p>
<br><p style='margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center'><font size=2>F-16</font></p><br><HR noshade align=center width="100%" size=2>
<p style="page-break-before: always" align="center"><font size=2>HUNGARIAN TELEPHONE
  AND CABLE CORP. AND SUBSIDIARY</font><br>
  <font size="2">Notes to </font><font size=2>Consolidated Financial Statements
  </font><br>
  <font size=2> December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000</font><PAGE>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>the Company. These universal service obligations are now incorporated in a Universal Service Agreement between the Company and the Ministry.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The link between the end of the concession agreements and the coming into force of the universal service obligations is recognised by Section 106(5) of the Communications Act, which states that &#147;In connection with the amendment of concession agreements to ensure the provision of the universal service, the Minister may, in justified cases, reduce the concession fee payment liability or release service providers therefrom, and, in parallel with the conclusion of the universal service agreement, may initiate the termination of the concession contract by mutual agreement&#148;.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Universal Service Agreement states that &#147;the Parties undertake to start bona fide negotiations within 30 days of the execution of this Agreement regarding the amendment or cancellation of the concession contract provisions remaining in force&#148;. These negotiations are currently in progress. The Company believes that the request from the Minister to pay the annual concession fees for (a) 2001 is subject to a counterclaim by the Company arising as a result of the State replacing the concession system with the notification system and (b) 2002 is based on groundless arguments and is a breach of the equal treatment clause (referred to above) in the concession agreements.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>Accordingly, the Company believes that it is unlikely that the Minister will be able to successfully enforce its claim in respect of the annual concession fees for 2002. </font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(c)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Service Quality Criteria</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Universal Services Agreement provides for certain performance criteria, including deadlines for installing subscriber access, error response times and voice and date transfer quality. The performance parameters are detailed in the Universal Services Agreement and failure to meet them will result in a financial penalty linked to the degree of the failure in each case. As in the case of the performance requirements contained in the concession agreements, the Company believes it has fulfilled the performance requirements thus far, and will continue to do so, in all material respects. In addition to the above, if the Company ceases to fulfil its obligations under the Universal Services Agreement for unlawful reasons for which it is responsible, a fixed penalty of HUF 150 million (approximately $0.7 million at December 31, 2002 exchange rates) would be payable per geographical area per occasion by the Company.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(d)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Hungarian Ownership</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>In the concession agreements with Hungarotel and one of its predecessor companies, as amended on June 3, 1996, the Ministry stipulated that each comply with certain Hungarian ownership requirements so that by June 3, 2003, Hungarian ownership must consist of at least 25% plus one share. For the period between June 3, 1996 and June 3, 2003, Hungarian ownership must be at least 10%, except that during such period, Hungarian ownership may be reduced to as low as 1% for a period of up to two years. During the seven-year period, while the Hungarian ownership block is required to be at least 10%, that 10% equity holding must have voting power of at least 25% plus one share, thus providing Hungarian owners the right to block certain transactions which, under Hungarian corporate law, require a supermajority (75%) of stockholders voting on the matter, such as mergers and consolidations, increases in share capital
and winding-up.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>For these purposes, &#147;Hungarian ownership&#148; means shares owned by Hungarian citizens. Shares owned by a corporation are considered Hungarian owned only in proportion to the Hungarian ownership of such corporation. The concession holding company can also fulfill the 25% plus one share Hungarian ownership requirement by listing their shares on the Budapest Stock Exchange.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Hungarian ownership requirements in the concession agreements with two of Hungarotel&#146;s other predecessor companies call for a strict 25% plus one share Hungarian ownership. However, the Ministry stated, pursuant to a letter dated September 18, 1996, that it intended that all of Hungarotel&#146;s predecessor companies be treated equally with respect to such ownership requirements.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>Following a capital transaction with Postabank in May 1999, Hungarotel is deemed in compliance with the 10% ownership requirement, however it is not currently in compliance with the 25% voting requirement. Failure to comply with the 25% Hungarian ownership requirement at the end of the seven-</font></p>
<br><p style='margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center'><font size=2>F-17</font></p><br><HR noshade align=center width="100%" size=2>
<p style="page-break-before: always" align="center"><font size=2>HUNGARIAN TELEPHONE
  AND CABLE CORP. AND SUBSIDIARY</font><br>
  <font size="2">Notes to </font><font size=2>Consolidated Financial Statements
  </font><br>
  <font size=2> December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000</font><PAGE>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>year period, which expires in 2003, might be considered a serious breach of a concession agreement, giving the Ministry the right, among other things, to terminate the concession agreements. However, as stated above, the Company is in the process of negotiating with the Ministry on the mutual termination of these concession agreements, which may remove the Hungarian ownership requirements.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The content, effect or timing of any amended terms are unknown at the present time, however, the Company believes that it will be able to negotiate new ownership terms satisfactory to both it and the Ministry. In giving his consent to the December 31, 2001 merger of Hungarotel and its predecessor companies, the then Minister urged Hungarotel to take all reasonable steps to comply with the Hungarian ownership rules and stated that, in the meantime, it should continue to ensure that Hungarian representation on the company&#146;s management bodies corresponds to a 25%+1 share shareholding, regardless of the actual shareholdings.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(e)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Construction Commitments</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company has a long-term frame contract with Siemens which provides for the continued expansion of a local telephone network and the addition of new subscribers in one of its operating areas. $1.2 million (at December 31, 2002 exchange rates) of this contract remains to be spent.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company has signed an agreement with a cable television operator in one of its operating areas to split the groundwork and pavement reconstruction costs in installing an underground cable duct system. The final phase of this network construction project is expected to be completed during 2003 in the amount of approximately $0.5 million (at December 31, 2002 exchange rates).</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(f)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Leases</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company and its subsidiaries lease office and other facilities in the United States and Hungary, which require minimum annual rentals. Rent expense under operating lease agreements for the years ended December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000, was $411,000, $296,000 and $301,000, respectively, and is included in operating and maintenance expenses. Lease obligations for each of the next five years are as follows (at December 31, 2002 exchange rates): 2003, $524,000; 2004, $528,000; 2005, $546,000; 2006, $565,000; and 2007, $585,000.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(g)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Legal Proceedings</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>During 1996 and 1997, Hungarotel entered into several construction contracts with a Hungarian contractor, which totaled $59.0 million in the aggregate, $47.5 million of which was financed by a contractor financing facility. By January 1998, it became clear to Hungarotel that there were problems with the work undertaken by the contractor and Hungarotel rejected invoices in the amount of approximately HUF 700 million (approximately $3.1 million at December 31, 2002 exchange rates) for, among other reasons, the contractor&#146;s failure to meet the contractual capacity requirements and breaches of warranties regarding the quality of work. The contractor subsequently sought payment under separate invoices in the amount of approximately $24 million at historical exchange rates, which Hungarotel disputes because of quantity and quality issues. During 1998, the Company and the contractor engaged in settlement
discussions in order to resolve these issues but were unable to reach a settlement. In addition to its contractual defense and a counterclaim for breach of contract by the contractor, amounting to approximately $31 million, at historical exchange rates, Hungarotel acquired a claim of HUF 4.0 billion against the contractor in 1999, following a series of transactions with the contractor&#146;s major creditor. Against this HUF 4.0 billion, Hungarotel offset the amount of HUF 900 million in respect of invoices from the contractor to Hungarotel that were accepted but unpaid. The remaining HUF 3.1 billion net claim (approximately $13.8 million at December 31, 2002 exchange rates) serves as security in the event the contractor commences proceedings against Hungarotel. </font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>In July 2001, the contractor filed an additional lawsuit challenging certain transactions regarding litigated matters between the contractor&#146;s creditor and the Company. The first hearing regarding this action was held in April 2002, but was adjourned to March 12, 2003, now further adjourned at the court&#146;s request to May 12, 2003. The Company believes that this additional lawsuit is without merit and that the Company will prevail.</font></p>
<br><p style='margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center'><font size=2>F-18</font></p><br><HR noshade align=center width="100%" size=2>
<p style="page-break-before: always" align="center"><font size=2>HUNGARIAN TELEPHONE
  AND CABLE CORP. AND SUBSIDIARY</font><br>
  <font size="2">Notes to </font><font size=2>Consolidated Financial Statements
  </font><br>
  <font size=2> December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000</font><PAGE>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>In December 1999, a debt collection company initiated debt collection proceedings against the Hungarian contractor for non-payment of various debts. In June 2000, the debt collection company claimed the benefit of certain invoices that the contractor had issued to Hungarotel in the amount of HUF 455 million (approximately $2.0 million at December 31, 2002 exchange rates), stating that the contractor had assigned those invoices to it &#147;as security&#148; in the debt collection proceedings. Hungarotel rejected the debt collection company&#146;s claim for, among other reasons, the absence of a right by the contractor to assign the invoices and that, in any event, Hungarotel has a substantive defense and counterclaim on the merits to the underlying claim on the invoices. After a court hearing in November 2001, the debt collection company reduced its claim against Hungarotel to HUF 250 million
(approximately $1.1 million at December 31, 2002 exchange rates) (and proportionally reduced the amount of interest claimed) because it could not substantiate the HUF 455 million claim on the basis of the contractor&#146;s assignment agreement. At a further hearing in December 2001, the court terminated the proceedings, on the grounds that it had no jurisdiction to deal with the matter because the terms of the contract between Hungarotel and the contractor states that disputes surrounding the contract are to be resolved through arbitration proceedings. The debt collection company has appealed this decision to the Hungarian Supreme Court. The Supreme Court upheld the appeal and ordered the matter be returned to the lower court. The next hearing at the lower court has been scheduled for August 25, 2003. The Company believes that it will prevail. </font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company and its subsidiary are involved in various other claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of business. In the opinion of management, the ultimate disposition of these matters and those described above will not have a material effect on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial position, results of operations or liquidity. </font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(9)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><u><font size=2>Common Stock and Cumulative Convertible Preferred Stock</font></u></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>During the fourth quarter of 2000, the Company entered into an agreement with the International Finance Corporation (&#147;IFC&#148;), pursuant to which the IFC agreed to exchange its 20% ownership interest in a former subsidiary of the Company, which was merged into Hungarotel, for a total of 72,000 shares of the Company&#146;s common stock. The value of the shares on the date of issue totaled $333,000, which was recorded as an increase in Common Stock and additional paid-in capital.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>During the first quarter of 2001, Tele Danmark exercised its preemptive rights to maintain its ownership percentage in the Company. As a result of this exercise, the Company issued 14,001 shares of the Company&#146;s common stock in exchange for $98,000.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>As of December 31, 2002 and 2001, the Company had 30,000 shares of its cumulative convertible preferred stock, with a $70 liquidation value per share, outstanding. Any holder of the cumulative convertible preferred stock is entitled to receive cumulative cash dividends payable in arrears, at an annual rate of 5%, compounded annually on the liquidation value of $70 per share. The Company may, at its option, redeem the Preferred Stock at any time. The Cumulative Convertible Preferred Stock is convertible into shares of the Company&#146;s common stock on a one for ten basis. As of December 31, 2002 and 2001, the total arrearage on the cumulative convertible preferred stock was $386,000 and $282,000, respectively, and is included in due to related parties.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company has reserved 3,736,192 shares as of December 31, 2002 for issuance under stock option plans, compensation agreements, warrants and under the conversion terms applicable to its outstanding cumulative convertible preferred stock.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(10)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><u><font size=2>Stock Based Compensation</font></u></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>Stock
  Option Plans</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company adopted a stock option plan (the &#147;Plan&#148;) in April 1992 which provided for the issuance of an aggregate of 90,000 stock options, which has since been increased following stockholder approval, to 1,250,000 as of December 31, 2002. Under the Plan, incentive and non-qualified options may be granted to officers, directors and consultants to the Company. The plan is administered by the Compensation &#150; Stock Option Committee of the Board of Directors. Options granted under the Plan are exercisable for up to 10 years from the date of grant. As of December 31, 2002, 813,490 options provided for by the Plan had been issued, of which 198,100 were exercised and 615,390 remained outstanding.</font></p>
<br><p style='margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center'><font size=2>F-19</font></p><br><HR noshade align=center width="100%" size=2>
<p style="page-break-before: always" align="center"><font size=2>HUNGARIAN TELEPHONE
  AND CABLE CORP. AND SUBSIDIARY</font><br>
  <font size="2">Notes to </font><font size=2>Consolidated Financial Statements
  </font><br>
  <font size=2> December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000</font><PAGE>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>During 2000, a former officer exercised options to purchase 28,600 shares of Common Stock at $8.00 per share. Proceeds from the exercise of these options totaled $228,800. During 2001, a former officer exercised options to purchase 2,000 shares of Common Stock at $8.00 per share. Proceeds from the exercise of these options totaled $16,000. The options exercised were issued from the Company&#146;s stock option plan.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>In 1997, the Company adopted a director stock option plan (the &#147;Directors&#146; Plan&#148;) which provides for the issuance of an aggregate of 250,000 stock options. Options granted under the Directors&#146; Plan are exercisable for up to 10 years from the date of grant. As of December 31, 2002, 133,555 options provided for by the Directors&#146; Plan had been issued, of which 10,000 were exercised and 123,555 remained outstanding. </font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>During 2000, a former director exercised options, granted from the Directors&#146; Plan, to purchase 5,000 shares of Common Stock at $6.78 per share. Proceeds from the exercise of these options totaled $33,900.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company applies APB Opinion No. 25 and related interpretations in measuring compensation cost under its stock based compensation plans, including the Directors&#146; Plan. As a result of a modification to the options of a former employee, the Company has recognized a compensation expense of $72,000 in 2002, while in 2001 and 2000, the Company recognized a benefit of $9,000 and $45,000, respectively. The exercise price of all remaining options has equaled or exceeded the fair market value of the Company&#146;s common stock price at the respective grant dates and therefore, no compensation expense has been recognized by the Company. Had the Company determined compensation cost for options issued under the plans based on the fair value at the grant date in conformity with SFAS No. 123, the Company&#146;s net pro forma earnings (loss) and earnings (loss) per share would have been as follows:</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt;'>&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<td width=16 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p ><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td width=57 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:right;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=2>($0.50</font></p> </td>
<td width=16 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p ><font size=2>)</font></p> </td> </tr> </table>
<br>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>For purposes of the pro forma calculation under SFAS 123, the fair value of each option grant has been estimated on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model with the following assumptions: (1) a risk free rate of 5.36% in 2002, 5.09% in 2001 and 6.69% in 2000, (2) an expected life of 10 years for 2002, 6 years for 2001 and 6 years for 2000, and (3) volatility of approximately 60% for 2002, 76% for 2001 and 72% for 2000.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The following is a summary of stock options, including those issued under the Plan and Directors&#146; Plan referred to above, and other compensation agreements which were granted, and exercised and that have expired for the three years ended December 31, 2002:</font></p>

  <tr>
    <td colspan="8" valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>
      <div align="center"><b><font size=1>Options Outstanding</font></b><b></b></div>
    </td>
    <td valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'>&nbsp;</td>

</table>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:12pt;'><font size=2>Stock Grants</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>In November 1999, the Company cancelled 30,000 fully vested employee stock options with an original exercise price of $8.00 per share and an expiration date of March 31, 2003, and issued 30,000 options with like terms, except that the newly issued options have been granted with an exercise price of $5.46 per share, the fair value of such options at the date of modification. As a result of this modification, the Company has recognized approximately $72,000 of compensation expense in 2002, and $9,000 and $45,000 of compensation income in 2001 and 2000, respectively. </font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; text-indent:-0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(11)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><u><font size=2>Foreign Exchange Rate Gains (Losses)</font></u></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company&#146;s foreign exchange gains (losses) are primarily the result of the Company marking to market debt obligations not denominated in Hungarian forints during the year. The foreign exchange gains for the year ended December 31, 2002 resulted primarily from the effect of the appreciation of the Hungarian forint on the Company&#146;s average EUR 71.9 million and U.S. dollar 25 million denominated debt outstanding during the year. At December 31, 2002, the Hungarian forint had appreciated in value by 4.5% against the euro and by 23.9% against the U.S. dollar as compared to December 31, 2001. The foreign exchange gains for the year ended December 31, 2001 resulted primarily from the effect of the appreciation of the Hungarian forint on the Company&#146;s average EUR 84.3 million denominated debt outstanding during that year. At December 31, 2001, the Hungarian forint had appreciated in value by 7.6%
against the euro and by 2.0% against the U.S. dollar as compared to December 31, 2000. The foreign exchange loss for the year ended December 31, 2000 resulted primarily from the effect of the devaluation on the Company&#146;s average EUR 88 million and U.S. dollar 25 million denominated debt outstanding during that year. At December 31, 2000, the Hungarian forint had </font></p>
<br><p style='margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center'><font size=2>F-21</font></p><br><HR noshade align=center width="100%" size=2>
<p style="page-break-before: always" align="center"><font size=2>HUNGARIAN TELEPHONE
  AND CABLE CORP. AND SUBSIDIARY</font><br>
  <font size="2">Notes to </font><font size=2>Consolidated Financial Statements
  </font><br>
  <font size=2> December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000</font><PAGE>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>devalued
  by approximately 4% against the euro and by approximately 11% against the U.S.
  dollar as compared to December 31, 1999.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(12)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><u><font size=2>Reconciliation of Net Income (Loss) to Net Cash Provided by Operating Activities</font></u></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The reconciliation of net income (loss) to net cash provided by operating activities for the years ended December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000 follows:</font></p>

<br>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>Summary of non-cash transactions:</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>During 2000 the Company:</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:1.08in; text-indent:-0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2><b><font size=2>&#149;</font></b></font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Issued 72,000 shares of Common Stock valued at $333,000 to the IFC in exchange for its interest in one operating subsidiary.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(13)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><u><font size=2>Related Parties</font></u></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>Transactions entered into with certain related parties are as follows:</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(a)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Transactions with former officers and directors</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>On July 26, 1996, the Company entered into Termination and Release Agreements, Consulting Agreements and Non-competition Agreements with its former (x) Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, (y) former Vice Chairman and (z) former Chief Financial Officer, Treasurer, Secretary and Director. Pursuant to these agreements, the Company agreed to make payments for severance, consulting fees and non-compete agreements amounting to $7.25 million, in equal monthly instalments over a 72 month period which commenced August 31, 1996 and which ended on July 31, 2002, and also issued options to purchase 200,000 shares of Common Stock at an exercise price of $14.00 per share which expired unexercised in 2001. These commitments were supported by letters of credit. The Company recorded a charge of approximately $6.3 million in 1996 and has made payments aggregating </font></p>
<br><p style='margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center'><font size=2>F-22</font></p><br><HR noshade align=center width="100%" size=2>
<p style="page-break-before: always" align="center"><font size=2>HUNGARIAN TELEPHONE
  AND CABLE CORP. AND SUBSIDIARY</font><br>
  <font size="2">Notes to </font><font size=2>Consolidated Financial Statements
  </font><br>
  <font size=2> December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000</font><PAGE>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>approximately $0.7 million in 2002 and $1.2 million in each of 2001 and 2000 related to these agreements.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(b)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Transactions with TDC A/S </font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>TDC A/S&#146;s (&#147;Tele Danmark&#148;) share ownership in the Company is 31.9% of the Company&#146;s outstanding common stock as of December 31, 2002. Tele Danmark has been granted preemptive rights to maintain its ownership percentage. There were no material transactions with Tele Danmark for the years ended December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(c)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Transactions with Postabank</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>Postabank&#146;s share ownership in the Company is 20.1% of the Company&#146;s outstanding common stock as of December 31, 2002. Postabank receives interest from the Company under the Company&#146;s Notes, as well as being a member of the Company&#146;s European banking syndicate under its Credit Facility. Postabank also provides banking services to the Company which the Company believes are arms length in nature.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.39in;text-align:justify; margin-top:12pt;'><font size=2>(d)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font size=2>Transactions with Citizens</font><b><font size=2> </font></b><font size=2>Communications Company</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.79in;text-align:justify; margin-top:12pt;'><font size=2>As of December 31, 2002, Citizens Communications Company (&#147;Citizens&#148;) held 19.1% of the Company&#146;s outstanding common stock.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>Amounts payable to related parties as of December 31, 2002 and 2001, were as follows:</font></p>

<br>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The amount due to Citizens represents the accumulated, unpaid dividend on the Company&#146;s cumulative convertible preferred stock.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(14)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><u><font size=2>Employee Benefit Plan</font></u></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>Effective December 1996, the Company established a 401(k) salary deferral plan (the &#147;401(k) Plan&#148;) on behalf of its U.S. employees. The 401(k) Plan is a qualified defined contribution plan, and allows participating employees to defer up to 15% of their compensation, subject to certain limitations. Under the 401(k) Plan, the Company has the discretion to match contributions made by the employee. No matching contributions were made by the Company in 2002, 2001 or 2000.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(15)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><u><font size=2>Segment Disclosures</font></u></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company operates in a single industry segment, telecommunications services. The Company&#146;s operations involve developing and constructing a modern telecommunications infrastructure in order to provide a full range of the Company&#146;s products and services in its five concession areas in Hungary. While the Company&#146;s chief operating decision maker monitors the revenue streams of the various products and services, operations are managed and financial performance is evaluated based on the delivery of multiple services to customers over an integrated network. Substantially all of the Company&#146;s assets are located in Hungary and all of its operating revenues are generated in Hungary.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>Products and Services  </font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company groups its products and services into the following categories:</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><i><font size=2>Telephone Services</font></i><font size=2> &#150; local dial tone and switched products and services that provide incoming and outgoing calls over the public switched network. This category includes reciprocal compensation revenues and expenses (i.e. interconnect).</font></p>
<br><p style='margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center'><font size=2>F-23</font></p><br><HR noshade align=center width="100%" size=2>
<p style="page-break-before: always" align="center"><font size=2>HUNGARIAN TELEPHONE
  AND CABLE CORP. AND SUBSIDIARY</font><br>
  <font size="2">Notes to </font><font size=2>Consolidated Financial Statements
  </font><br>
  <font size=2> December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000</font><PAGE>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><i><font size=2>Network Services</font></i><font size=2> &#150; point-to-point dedicated services that provide a private transmission channel for the Company&#146;s customers&#146; exclusive use between two or more locations, both in local and long distance applications.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><i><font size=2>Other Service and Product Revenues</font></i><font size=2> &#150; PBX hardware sales and service revenues, as well as miscellaneous other telephony service revenues.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The revenues generated by these products and services for the years ended December 31 were as follows:</font></p>

<br>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>Major Customers</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>For the years ended December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000, none of the Company&#146;s customers accounted for more than 10% of the Company&#146;s total revenue.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(16)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><u><font size=2>Restricted Net Assets of Consolidated Subsidiaries</font></u></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.36in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The Company&#146;s Hungarian subsidiaries are restricted from paying dividends to HTCC under the Company&#146;s Senior Secured Debt Facility Agreement. As of December 31, 2002, net assets of the Hungarian subsidiaries amounted to approximately $39.8 million (at December 31, 2002 exchange rates), all of which is restricted.</font></p>

<br><p style='margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center'><font size=2>F-24</font></p><br><HR noshade align=center width="100%" size=2><p style="page-break-before: always"><PAGE>

<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center; margin-top:16pt;'><font SIZE=2>HUNGARIAN TELEPHONE AND CABLE CORP. AND SUBSIDIARY</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center; margin-top:16pt;'><font size=2>Schedule I &#150; Condensed Financial Statements of Registrant</font><br><font size=2>Hungarian Telephone and Cable Corp.</font><br><font size=2>Condensed Statements of Operations</font><br><font size=2>Years ended December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000</font><br><font size=2>(In thousands, except share and per share data)</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:0pt;'>&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<table width="100%" border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style='border-collapse:collapse; '> <tr>
<td valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:center;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;' ><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td width=15 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:center;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td colspan=2 valign=bottom style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='text-align:center;margin-top:2pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><b><font size=1>2002</font></b></p> </td>

<br><p style='margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center'><font size=2>S-4</font></p><br><HR noshade align=center width="100%" size=2><p style="page-break-before: always"><PAGE>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center; margin-top:16pt;'><font SIZE=2>HUNGARIAN TELEPHONE AND CABLE CORP. AND SUBSIDIARY</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center; margin-top:16pt;'><font size=2>Schedule I &#150; Condensed Financial Statements of Registrant</font><br><font size=2>Hungarian Telephone and Cable Corp.</font><br><font size=2>Notes to Condensed Financial Statements</font><br><font size=2>Years Ended December 31, 2002, 2001 and 2000</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-top:6pt;'><font size=2>(1)</font><font size=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><u><font size=2>Description of Business and Other Related Matters</font></u></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The accompanying condensed financial statements of Hungarian Telephone and Cable Corp. (&#147;HTCC&#148; or the &#147;Registrant&#148;) have been prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (&#147;U.S. GAAP&#148;). In preparing the financial statements, management is required to make estimates and assumptions that affect reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements, and revenue and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>HTCC&#146;s only source of cash is payments from inter-company loans and payments under its management service and loan guarantee agreements and dividends, if any, from its Hungarian subsidiary (the &#147;subsidiary&#148;). The subsidiary&#146;s ability to pay dividends or make other capital distributions to HTCC is governed by Hungarian law, and is significantly restricted by certain obligations of the subsidiary. The subsidiary is the borrower under a Banking Credit Facility which provides that the subsidiary can only make distributions to HTCC for limited purposes (i.e. management services), which does not include dividends.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>The
  condensed financial statements should be read in conjunction with the audited
  consolidated financial statements of Hungarian Telephone and Cable Corp. and
  its subsidiaries as of December 31, 2002 and 2001, and for the years ended December
  31, 2002, 2001 and 2000, including the notes thereto, set forth in the Company&#146;s
  consolidated financial statements appearing on pages F-3 through F-24 of the
  accompanying Form 10-K.</font></p>
<p style=' margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:0.72in; margin-top:8pt;'><font size=2>In
  2000, approximately $61.7 million of $79.0 million advanced as loan during 1999
  to its subsidiary was converted into equity in the subsidiary.</font></p>
<br><p style='margin-bottom:0pt;text-align:center'><font size=2>S-5</font></p><br><HR noshade align=center width="100%" size=2>
<p style="page-break-before: always"><u><b><font size=2>Schedule II - Valuation
  Accounts</font></b></u>

<td valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=2>Powers of Attorney</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr style='height:.05in'>
<td width=88 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in; height:.05in'> <p style='margin-bottom:0pt;margin-top:0in;'><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
<td valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in; height:.05in'> <p style='margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=1>&nbsp;</font></p> </td> </tr> <tr>
<td width=88 valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='margin-bottom:0pt;margin-top:0in;'><font size=2>99.1</font></p> </td>
<td valign=top style='padding:0in 0in 0in 0in'> <p style='margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt;'><font size=2>Certifications of Chief Executive Officer and Principal Financial Officer</font></p> </td> </tr> </table>

<DESCRIPTION>EXHIBIT 10.7
